nodes.bodyText: Does the same as the overridden method, should be removed.
This class is extended for all databases, please add javadoc for this method so that subclassers know what it is for.

In general you cannot assume it's going to be a Literal, functions must work with whatever expression they are given as input. The existing function, without the postgresql encoding, would work even if the pointer was specified with a complex expression, possibly attribute based.
If you check SQLDialect, it gets called for splitting filters. For this case, I suggest to override it, and check if there is a pointer function, and if the function is called in a "static" way. Static does not mean "literal" directly, it just means that the expression tree referenced by  "pointer" :

does not use any attribute
does not use any VolatileFunction

If those conditions are met, you can include the function in the capabilities, otherwise, you exclude it from them and have the splitter move it to the post-filter.
I think (please verify) that the JDBCDataStore code makes the filter go through a SimplfyingFilterVisitor, which is already doing this job for you:

  
    
      geotools/modules/library/main/src/main/java/org/geotools/filter/visitor/SimplifyingFilterVisitor.java
    
    
         Line 453
      in
      029dc5c
    
    
    
    

        
          
           public Object visit(org.opengis.filter.expression.Function function, Object extraData) { 
        
    
  


If so, all you need to do is to write a DefaultFilterVisitor, if it finds a JSONPointerFunction, it means it was not eliminated by the simplifier, and thus it's dynamic, cannot be encoded in SQL.
thanks for the point and the explanation, fixed
Please add a test for nested properties, like a/b (instead of array case) and also one for a non-encodable case, like, the pointer value is contained in a second attribute of the feature.

Thread safety issue here. The capabilities object is big and normally shared, you should not be modifying it. Since it's large, cloning it is also somehow expensive.
Suggestion: change the PostPreProcessFilterSplittingVisitor so that the "!fcs.supports(expression.getClass())" check is delegated to a separate method that you can override here.
The filter to sql will fail if the expression is not a Literal though (class cast exception).

Never mind, I see you are replacing it with a Literal... however, you should not be modifying the filter here, unless you are sure it has been through a copy first, otherwise you risk changing some cached state (e.g., the structure of a in memory SLD representation, or some such).
